title: Synthetic Recap
body:
MIAMI — On a night where the final score read 96-95, the real story was a singular, historic force of nature wearing Seattle green. Gary Payton didn’t just beat the Miami Heat; he authored a masterpiece, pouring in a career-high 44 points and dragging the SuperSonics to a heart-stopping road victory.

From the opening tip, this was The Glove’s showcase. Payton was unstoppable, slicing through the Miami defense with a relentless combination of drives and pull-up jumpers. His 44-point eruption was not just a season-high; it was a statement performance, a virtuoso display of scoring prowess that left the Heat scrambling for answers all night. While Hersey Hawkins provided a crucial 17-point supporting role, the entire arena knew every Sonics possession was a referendum on Payton’s will.

Miami fought valiantly, led by Tim Hardaway’s 23 points and a dominant 18-point, 17-rebound double-double from Alonzo Mourning. But even Mourning’s immense presence in the paint couldn’t extinguish Payton’s fire. The game teetered in the final seconds, the outcome hanging on a single point.

In the end, it was Payton’s monumental effort—every one of those 44 points essential—that provided the final, narrow margin. He didn't just lead his team; he carried it across the finish line in one of the most spectacular individual performances of the 1997 season, a night that will forever be etched in the annals of SuperSonics history.
